elements.content: A flexible and hydrolytically stable metal–organic framework [Mn­(H2O)2­(Fc­(PHOO)2)­·2H2O] n has been synthesized using ferrocene-based ligand bearing phosphinic groups (Fc­(PHOOH)2 = 1,1′-ferrocenediyl-bis­(H-phosphinic acid)). In this compound manganese atoms are bound by phosphinate fragments to give infinite chains, and the latter are interconnected by ferrocene groups to form two-dimensional coordination polymer. The elimination of both coordinated and lattice water molecules during heating up to 150 °C produced the compound, which is nonporous for nitrogen, but can selectively adsorb water over methanol and other solvents at 298 K. The reversible structural transformation during adsorption/desorption of water is also reflected in a change of magnetic properties of the metal–organic framework.
elements.clean_text: A flexible and hydrolytically stable metal-organic framework [Mn(H2O)2(Fc(PHOO)2)⋅2H2O] n  has been synthesized using ferrocene-based ligand bearing phosphinic groups (Fc(PHOOH)2 = 1,1'-ferrocenediyl-bis(H-phosphinic acid)). In this compound manganese atoms are bound by phosphinate fragments to give infinite chains, and the latter are interconnected by ferrocene groups to form two-dimensional coordination polymer. The elimination of both coordinated and lattice water molecules during heating up to 150 °C produced the compound, which is nonporous for nitrogen, but can selectively adsorb water over methanol and other solvents at 298 K. The reversible structural transformation during adsorption/desorption of water is also reflected in a change of magnetic properties of the metal-organic framework.

elements.content: The synthesized flexible metal−organic framework based on phosphinic acid demonstrates reversible crystal structure transformation and is able to exist in two stable forms: hydrated Mn­(H2O)2­(Fc­(PHOO)2)­·2H2O and dehydrated Mn­(Fc­(PHOO)2). The dehydrated compound can adsorb H2O molecules selectively over other possible adsorptives. The structural transformations are also reflected in a change of magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: The synthesized flexible metal-organic framework based on phosphinic acid demonstrates reversible crystal structure transformation and is able to exist in two stable forms: hydrated Mn(H2O)2(Fc(PHOO)2)⋅2H2O and dehydrated Mn(Fc(PHOO)2). The dehydrated compound can adsorb H2O molecules selectively over other possible adsorptives. The structural transformations are also reflected in a change of magnetic properties.

elements.content: Flexible or dynamic metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) of the third generation according to the Kitagawa classification also called soft porous crystals can undergo reversible structural transformations upon adsorption/desorption of guest molecules. These changes may involve the shrinkage of the pores upon desorption and the adjustment of pore size and shape to accommodate guest molecules during the adsorption process. The transformations may be accompanied by the cleavage and formation of coordination bonds, by the change of the framework dimensionality, by the change of the metal coordination polyhedra, the slippage of the layers, mechanical shrinkage of crystals, etc. In these processes the crystallinity is often retained, but in some cases the crystalline-to-amorphous-to-crystalline transformations take place.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Flexible or dynamic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) of the third generation according to the Kitagawa classification also called soft porous crystals can undergo reversible structural transformations upon adsorption/desorption of guest molecules. These changes may involve the shrinkage of the pores upon desorption and the adjustment of pore size and shape to accommodate guest molecules during the adsorption process. The transformations may be accompanied by the cleavage and formation of coordination bonds, by the change of the framework dimensionality, by the change of the metal coordination polyhedra, the slippage of the layers, mechanical shrinkage of crystals, etc. In these processes the crystallinity is often retained, but in some cases the crystalline-to-amorphous-to-crystalline transformations take place.

elements.content: The fascinating flexibility phenomena (involving gating and berating) in MOFs offer a wide range of application opportunities emerging when structural transformations upon adsorption/desorption are accompanied by the simultaneous changes of physical properties. In particular, the adsorption/desorption of water molecules was shown to influence the color of the MOFs, adsorption selectivity, proton conductivity, luminescence, and magnetic properties. The latter may involve pure quantitative changes, as well as more significant effects, such as the switch of exchange interactions between the metal ions from ferromagnetic to antiferromagnetic, from ferrimagnetic to suppressed ferrimagnetic, from soft to hard magnetism, and spin crossover effect.
elements.clean_text: The fascinating flexibility phenomena (involving gating and berating) in MOFs offer a wide range of application opportunities emerging when structural transformations upon adsorption/desorption are accompanied by the simultaneous changes of physical properties. In particular, the adsorption/desorption of water molecules was shown to influence the color of the MOFs, adsorption selectivity, proton conductivity, luminescence, and magnetic properties. The latter may involve pure quantitative changes, as well as more significant effects, such as the switch of exchange interactions between the metal ions from ferromagnetic to antiferromagnetic, from ferrimagnetic to suppressed ferrimagnetic, from soft to hard magnetism, and spin crossover effect.

elements.content: Most of the soft porous crystals are constructed of metal containing inorganic nodes and organic bridging ligands. The inorganic ligands are mostly halogens, cyano, and SCN groups, while organic linkers are mostly carboxylate and pyridine based ligands. MOFs based on phosphorus acids derivatives are poorly studied, mainly due to the conformational lability of the phosphinate or phosphonate fragments, making it difficult to obtain porous compounds of the second generation. On the other hand, the strong coordination bonds between the phosphinate anion and the transition metals suggest the formation of coordination compounds stable against hydrolysis. The chemical stability of MOFs is essential for most potential applications such as gas sorption, purification, separation and storage, catalysis, molecular sensing, contaminant removal, contrast agents, and drug delivery systems. Combining lability of phosphinate or phosphonate groups with a three-dimensional (3D) rigid fragment such as ferrocene, one can expect the formation of flexible and dynamic frameworks of the third generation. The ability of phosphinate and phosphonate groups to act as strong hydrogen bond acceptors can enhance the stability of the MOF and be crucial for its dynamic properties. The structural studies of coordination properties of phosphorus containing acids revealed their ability to bridge metals forming M–O–P–O–M stable fragments. In combination with magnetic ions the phosphinic acid may form magnetic coordination compounds with O–P–O bridges providing exchange interactions between the magnetic centers.
elements.clean_text: Most of the soft porous crystals are constructed of metal containing inorganic nodes and organic bridging ligands. The inorganic ligands are mostly halogens, cyano, and SCN groups, while organic linkers are mostly carboxylate and pyridine based ligands. MOFs based on phosphorus acids derivatives are poorly studied, mainly due to the conformational lability of the phosphinate or phosphonate fragments, making it difficult to obtain porous compounds of the second generation. On the other hand, the strong coordination bonds between the phosphinate anion and the transition metals suggest the formation of coordination compounds stable against hydrolysis. The chemical stability of MOFs is essential for most potential applications such as gas sorption, purification, separation and storage, catalysis, molecular sensing, contaminant removal, contrast agents, and drug delivery systems. Combining lability of phosphinate or phosphonate groups with a three-dimensional (3D) rigid fragment such as ferrocene, one can expect the formation of flexible and dynamic frameworks of the third generation. The ability of phosphinate and phosphonate groups to act as strong hydrogen bond acceptors can enhance the stability of the MOF and be crucial for its dynamic properties. The structural studies of coordination properties of phosphorus containing acids revealed their ability to bridge metals forming M-O-P-O-M stable fragments. In combination with magnetic ions the phosphinic acid may form magnetic coordination compounds with O-P-O bridges providing exchange interactions between the magnetic centers.

elements.content: Herein, we report the successful synthesis, crystal structure, magnetic properties and selective adsorption behavior of a two-dimensional (2D) MOF based on manganese­(II) and 1,1′-ferrocenediyl-bis­(H-phosphinic) acid (1), which is to the best of our knowledge, a first example of a flexible MOF based on a ferrocene containing ligand. This compound undergoes reversible structural transformation during water removal and sorption showing the “gate opening” behavior in the water adsorption isotherm, as well as simultaneous change of its magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the successful synthesis, crystal structure, magnetic properties and selective adsorption behavior of a two-dimensional (2D) MOF based on manganese(II) and 1,1'-ferrocenediyl-bis(H-phosphinic) acid (1), which is to the best of our knowledge, a first example of a flexible MOF based on a ferrocene containing ligand. This compound undergoes reversible structural transformation during water removal and sorption showing the "gate opening" behavior in the water adsorption isotherm, as well as simultaneous change of its magnetic properties.

elements.content:
All chemicals were used as purchased without further purification. The 1,1′-ferrocenediyl-bis­(H-phosphinic acid) (1) was prepared as previously described.

Synthesis of [Mn­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>­(Fc­(PHOO)<sub>2</sub>)­·2H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

MnCl2·4H2O (31.7 mg; 0.16 mmol) and Fc­(P­(O)­(H)­OH)2 (50.2 mg; 0.16 mmol) were dissolved in 4 mL of a water/acetone mixture (1:3). After several hours at room temperature, orange crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 67.3 mg (96%) based on 1,1′-ferrocenediyl-bis­(H-phosphinic acid).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Syntheses

All chemicals were used as purchased without further purification. The 1,1'-ferrocenediyl-bis(H-phosphinic acid) (1) was prepared as previously described. 

Synthesis of [Mn(H2O)2(Fc(PHOO)2)⋅2H2O] n  (2)

MnCl2⋅4H2O (31.7 mg; 0.16 mmol) and Fc(P(O)(H)OH)2 (50.2 mg; 0.16 mmol) were dissolved in 4 mL of a water/acetone mixture (1:3). After several hours at room temperature, orange crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 67.3 mg (96%) based on 1,1'-ferrocenediyl-bis(H-phosphinic acid).

elements.content: The compound 2′ was obtained by drying 2 under vacuum for 24 h at 150 °C. Removal of all solvent molecules was proved by thermogravimetric analysis. Anal. Calcd for 2′ C10H10FeMnO4P2 (366.91 g/mol): C: 32.70; H: 2.72%. Found: C: 32.53; H: 3.01%. IR (nujol, cm–1): 3386 w, 3097 w, 2340 m, 1574 w, 1425 m, 1313 w, 1189 vs, 1180 vs, 1163 vs, 1070 s, 1051 s, 1016 s, 986 s, 897 m, 837 m, 642 s, 472 s.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Mn(FcPHOO2)] n  (2')

The compound 2' was obtained by drying 2 under vacuum for 24 h at 150 °C. Removal of all solvent molecules was proved by thermogravimetric analysis. Anal. Calcd for 2' C10H10FeMnO4P2 (366.91 g/mol): C: 32.70; H: 2.72%. Found: C: 32.53; H: 3.01%. IR (nujol, cm-1): 3386 w, 3097 w, 2340 m, 1574 w, 1425 m, 1313 w, 1189 vs, 1180 vs, 1163 vs, 1070 s, 1051 s, 1016 s, 986 s, 897 m, 837 m, 642 s, 472 s.

elements.content:
Elemental analyses were carried out using CHNS-O high-temperature element analyzer Eurovector EuroEA3028-HT-OM.

IR spectra of solid 2 and 2′ have been recorded in the 400–4000 cm–1 range (optical resolution 4 cm–1). The samples prepared as nujol mulls were placed between KBr plates. IR spectra of 2 placed in a variable temperature cell (Specac) were registered using IFS66v/s vacuum FTIR spectrometer (Bruker). Starting from room temperature and up to 200 °C with 10 °C interval, each spectrum was recorded after 10 min temperature stabilization. At 140 °C IR spectra were recorded twice: after 10 and 90 min equilibration time. The IR spectra of samples 2′ were registered at room temperature using FTIR spectrometer Vector 22 (Bruker).
elements.clean_text:
Elemental analyses were carried out using CHNS-O high-temperature element analyzer Eurovector EuroEA3028-HT-OM.

IR spectra of solid 2 and 2' have been recorded in the 400-4000 cm-1 range (optical resolution 4 cm-1). The samples prepared as nujol mulls were placed between KBr plates. IR spectra of 2 placed in a variable temperature cell (Specac) were registered using IFS66v/s vacuum FTIR spectrometer (Bruker). Starting from room temperature and up to 200 °C with 10 °C interval, each spectrum was recorded after 10 min temperature stabilization. At 140 °C IR spectra were recorded twice: after 10 and 90 min equilibration time. The IR spectra of samples 2' were registered at room temperature using FTIR spectrometer Vector 22 (Bruker).

elements.content: Raman spectra were registered at room temperature using a BRUKER RAM II module (with a Ge detector operating at liquid nitrogen temperature) attached to a BRUKER VERTEX 70 FTIR spectrometer in the range 10–4000 cm–1 with an optical resolution of 4 cm–1. Raman scattering radiation was collected in a backscattering configuration. 1024 scans were averaged for each spectrum. A Nd:YAG laser with a wavelength of 1064 nm and power of 150–250 mW was used as the excitation source. The samples were inserted in a standard glass cell.
elements.clean_text: Raman spectra were registered at room temperature using a BRUKER RAM II module (with a Ge detector operating at liquid nitrogen temperature) attached to a BRUKER VERTEX 70 FTIR spectrometer in the range 10-4000 cm-1 with an optical resolution of 4 cm-1. Raman scattering radiation was collected in a backscattering configuration. 1024 scans were averaged for each spectrum. A Nd:YAG laser with a wavelength of 1064 nm and power of 150-250 mW was used as the excitation source. The samples were inserted in a standard glass cell.

elements.content: Physisorption experiments of nitrogen were performed at 77 K up to 1 bar using a Quadrasorb apparatus (Quantachrome Co.). Water and methanol vapor physisorption was investigated at 298 K using Hydrosorb 1000 apparatus (Quantachrome Co.).
elements.clean_text: Physisorption experiments of nitrogen were performed at 77 K up to 1 bar using a Quadrasorb apparatus (Quantachrome Co.). Water and methanol vapor physisorption was investigated at 298 K using Hydrosorb 1000 apparatus (Quantachrome Co.).

elements.content:
The thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out on air using a Netzsch STA 409 PC Luxx thermal analyzer and heating rate of 5°/min in the temperature region from 20 up to 1000 °C.

TG/differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis was performed using a simultaneous TG/DSC NETZSCH (Selb, Germany) STA449 F3 analyzer. An approximately 7 mg sample was placed in an Al2O3 crucible with a prehole on the lid and heated from 25 to 500 °C. The same empty crucible was used as the reference sample. High-purity argon was used with a gas flow rate of 50 mL/min. TG/DSC measurements were performed at heating rates of 10 K/min.
elements.clean_text:
The thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was carried out on air using a Netzsch STA 409 PC Luxx thermal analyzer and heating rate of 5°/min in the temperature region from 20 up to 1000 °C.

An approximately 7 mg sample was placed in an Al2O3 crucible with a prehole on the lid and heated from 25 to 500 °C. The same empty crucible was used as the reference sample. High-purity argon was used with a gas flow rate of 50 mL/min. TG/DSC measurements were performed at heating rates of 10 K/min.

elements.content: The data of single crystal 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296(2) K. Programs used: data collection APEX2, data reduction SAINTPlus, absorption correction SADABS, structure solution and refinement SHELX.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

The data of single crystal 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296(2) K. Programs used: data collection APEX2, data reduction SAINTPlus, absorption correction SADABS, structure solution and refinement SHELX.

elements.content: Formula C10H18FeMnO8P2, M = 438.97, a = 10.199(2), b = 5.5056(13), c = 13.333(3) Å, β = 99.605(2)°, V = 738.1(3) Å3, ρcalc = 1.975 g cm–3, μ = 2.091 mm–1, semiempirical absorption correction, Z = 2 (molecule in a special position), monoclinic, space group P21 /c (No. 14), ω scans, 5288 reflections collected (±h, ± k, ± l), [(sin θ)/λ] = 0.62 Å–1, 1449 independent (R int = 0.030) and 1156 observed reflections [I ≥ 2σ­(I)], 139 refined parameters, R = 0.028, wR 2 = 0.069, max. residual electron density 0.323 (−0.366) e·Å–3, hydrogen atoms were localized in the difference Fourier map and refined isotropically.

Crystal Data for 2 

Formula C10H18FeMnO8P2, M = 438.97, a = 10.199(2), b = 5.5056(13), c = 13.333(3) Å, β = 99.605(2)°, V = 738.1(3) Å3, ρcalc = 1.975 g cm-3, μ = 2.091 mm-1, semiempirical absorption correction, Z = 2 (molecule in a special position), monoclinic, space group P21 /c (No. 14), ω scans, 5288 reflections collected (±h, ± k, ± l), [(sin θ)/λ] = 0.62 Å-1, 1449 independent (R int = 0.030) and 1156 observed reflections [I ≥ 2σ(I)], 139 refined parameters, R = 0.028, wR 2 = 0.069, max. residual electron density 0.323 (-0.366) e⋅Å-3, hydrogen atoms were localized in the difference Fourier map and refined isotropically.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction data were collected on a STOE STADI P diffractometer with Cu–Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å). The powder diffraction pattern for as made 2 was measured on the KMC-2 beamline on BESSY (HZB Berlin).

elements.content:
Static magnetization measurements were performed on powder samples by means of a commercial SQUID-VSM magnetometer from Quantum Design at temperatures 1.8–300 K in magnetic fields up to 7 T.

Results and DiscussionSynthesis and Structure of [Mn­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>­(Fc­(PHOO)<sub>2</sub>)­·2H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Reaction of Mn­(II) chloride with Fc­(PHOOH)2 in a 1:1 molar ratio in a mixture of acetone and water yields orange single crystals of (2) with quantitative yield ().

The X-ray single crystal diffraction showed that complex 2 crystallizes in a monoclinic space group P21/c, the asymmetric unit containing half of the ligand, one Mn atom, one coordinated water molecule, and one solvate water molecule. The Mn atoms adopt octahedral coordination geometry with two water oxygen atoms being in the axial positions with the Mn–O distances of 2.283(2) Å and four oxygen atoms from different phosphinate groups in equatorial positions with Mn–O distances equal to 2.184(2) Å and 2.146(2) Å. Each phosphinate ligand doubly bridges two metal centers with the nonbonded Mn···Mn distance of about 5.5 Å resulting in an infinite chain. These chains are additionally stitched via ferrocenyl fragment to form a 2D network ().
elements.clean_text:
Static magnetization measurements were performed on powder samples by means of a commercial SQUID-VSM magnetometer from Quantum Design at temperatures 1.8-300 K in magnetic fields up to 7 T.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structure of [Mn(H2O)2(Fc(PHOO)2)⋅2H2O] n  (2)

Reaction of Mn(II) chloride with Fc(PHOOH)2 in a 1:1 molar ratio in a mixture of acetone and water yields orange single crystals of (2) with quantitative yield ().

The X-ray single crystal diffraction showed that complex 2 crystallizes in a monoclinic space group P21/c, the asymmetric unit containing half of the ligand, one Mn atom, one coordinated water molecule, and one solvate water molecule. The Mn atoms adopt octahedral coordination geometry with two water oxygen atoms being in the axial positions with the Mn-O distances of 2.283(2) Å and four oxygen atoms from different phosphinate groups in equatorial positions with Mn-O distances equal to 2.184(2) Å and 2.146(2) Å. Each phosphinate ligand doubly bridges two metal centers with the nonbonded Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance of about 5.5 Å resulting in an infinite chain. These chains are additionally stitched via ferrocenyl fragment to form a 2D network ().

elements.clean_text: 1  Formation of the Compound 2, Lattice Water Molecules Are Not Shown

elements.content: A fragment of a layer of compound 2. The lattice water molecules are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  A fragment of a layer of compound 2. The lattice water molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Such supramolecular arrangement is possible due to the conformational lability of the ferrocenyl fragment. Two phosphinic groups adopt trans-orientation to bridge the neighboring chains while according to density functional theory calculations the most stable conformer for the ligand itself is the one with cis-orientation of two phosphinic groups stabilized by strong intramolecular hydrogen bonding. Water molecules located in the axial positions of the Mn2+ coordination polyhedron are involved in hydrogen bonds with the lattice water molecules binding the 2D layers into a 3D structure (). Each lattice water molecule forms two hydrogen bonds with phosphinate oxygen atoms being also an acceptor of the hydrogen bonds with coordinated water. All three O···O distances vary from 2.84 to 2.91 Å. Thus, lattice water molecules are fixed in the crystal via multiple hydrogen bonding interactions, which provides the stability of the layered structure and allows location of hydrogen atoms from the difference Fourier syntheses using room temperature X-ray data. The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) data of the bulk sample 2 shows good agreement with the pattern simulated from the single crystal data (), proving its phase purity.
elements.clean_text: Such supramolecular arrangement is possible due to the conformational lability of the ferrocenyl fragment. Two phosphinic groups adopt trans-orientation to bridge the neighboring chains while according to density functional theory calculations the most stable conformer for the ligand itself is the one with cis-orientation of two phosphinic groups stabilized by strong intramolecular hydrogen bonding. Water molecules located in the axial positions of the Mn2+ coordination polyhedron are involved in hydrogen bonds with the lattice water molecules binding the 2D layers into a 3D structure (). Each lattice water molecule forms two hydrogen bonds with phosphinate oxygen atoms being also an acceptor of the hydrogen bonds with coordinated water. All three O⋅⋅⋅O distances vary from 2.84 to 2.91 Å. Thus, lattice water molecules are fixed in the crystal via multiple hydrogen bonding interactions, which provides the stability of the layered structure and allows location of hydrogen atoms from the difference Fourier syntheses using room temperature X-ray data. The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) data of the bulk sample 2 shows good agreement with the pattern simulated from the single crystal data (), proving its phase purity.

elements.content: The water molecules can be removed from the structure by heating (Figure S6). Compound 2 loses all four H2O molecules (coordinated and lattice water; 17 wt %) in the temperature range of 65–155 °C transforming into the dehydrated form Mn­(Fc­(PHOO)2) (2′) which is stable up to 260 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Transformations during Water Removal

The water molecules can be removed from the structure by heating (Figure S6). Compound 2 loses all four H2O molecules (coordinated and lattice water; 17 wt %) in the temperature range of 65-155 °C transforming into the dehydrated form Mn(Fc(PHOO)2) (2') which is stable up to 260 °C.

elements.content:
Temperature dependent powder X-ray analysis shows that the water loss is accompanied by the loss of the long-range order in the structure, e.g., by the loss of the crystallinity (Figure S7).

To shed light on structural effects accompanying this transition we studied IR spectra of pristine and dehydrated samples. The most significant differences in the spectra of 2 and 2′ are found, as expected, in the spectral regions, where water vibrations are active. The IR spectrum of 2 (Figure S4a) shows a strong broad band at ca. 3380 cm–1 associated with OH stretching vibrations of hydrogen-bonded water molecules (νOH). The band is of quite complex character that agrees with the X-ray data indicating two types of water molecules in crystal 2: (i) coordinated to Mn­(II) and (ii) interlayer molecules. The sharp band at 1637 cm–1 should be assigned to bending vibrations of water molecules coordinated to Mn­(II) ions (δ­(OH)). IR-spectra of 2′ species (Figure S4a) demonstrate the presence of some amount of water, but ν­(OH) bands centered at ∼3386 cm–1 are less strong than in the spectra of 2, being of comparable intensity with the neighboring band of CH stretchings at ∼3100 cm–1. The absence of a sharp δ­(OH) band at 1637 cm–1 suggests that the water molecules are not coordinated to Mn­(II) ions.
elements.clean_text:
Temperature dependent powder X-ray analysis shows that the water loss is accompanied by the loss of the long-range order in the structure, e.g., by the loss of the crystallinity (Figure S7).

To shed light on structural effects accompanying this transition we studied IR spectra of pristine and dehydrated samples. The most significant differences in the spectra of 2 and 2' are found, as expected, in the spectral regions, where water vibrations are active. The IR spectrum of 2 (Figure S4a) shows a strong broad band at ca. 3380 cm-1 associated with OH stretching vibrations of hydrogen-bonded water molecules (νOH). The band is of quite complex character that agrees with the X-ray data indicating two types of water molecules in crystal 2: (i) coordinated to Mn(II) and (ii) interlayer molecules. The sharp band at 1637 cm-1 should be assigned to bending vibrations of water molecules coordinated to Mn(II) ions (δ(OH)). IR-spectra of 2' species (Figure S4a) demonstrate the presence of some amount of water, but ν(OH) bands centered at ~3386 cm-1 are less strong than in the spectra of 2, being of comparable intensity with the neighboring band of CH stretchings at ~3100 cm-1. The absence of a sharp δ(OH) band at 1637 cm-1 suggests that the water molecules are not coordinated to Mn(II) ions.

elements.content: Apart from H2O bands discussed above some other bands indicated in Figure S4a undergo pronounced changes resulting from the above-mentioned transition. These bands assigned on the basis of computational analysis of the spectra (Figures S1 and S2, Table S1) are mainly associated with the HPO2 – moiety, which indicates a reorganization of electronic structure of this fragment caused by the destruction of its hydrogen bonds after the removing of water molecules. Nevertheless, a strong band at ca. 1150 cm–1 of antisymmetrical stretchings of the PO2 – group (νas PO2 –) coordinated to Mn­(II) is present in the IR spectra of all the forms studied (Figure S4a). This band is absent in the spectrum of 1,1′-ferrocenediyl-bis­(H-phosphinic acid). Thus, coordinative bonds (P)­O–Mn are still preserved in the dehydrated forms of complex 2. Further evidence of this is provided by comparison of Raman spectra of the acid Fc­(PHOOH)2 and crystals 2 and 2′ (Figure S3). The spectra of the latter two species in low-frequency region, where vibrations of the coordinative bonds are expected to contribute essentially, practically coincide with each other and differ essentially from the spectrum of the noncoordinated acid.
elements.clean_text: Apart from H2O bands discussed above some other bands indicated in Figure S4a undergo pronounced changes resulting from the above-mentioned transition. These bands assigned on the basis of computational analysis of the spectra (Figures S1 and S2, Table S1) are mainly associated with the HPO2 - moiety, which indicates a reorganization of electronic structure of this fragment caused by the destruction of its hydrogen bonds after the removing of water molecules. Nevertheless, a strong band at ca. 1150 cm-1 of antisymmetrical stretchings of the PO2 - group (νas PO2 -) coordinated to Mn(II) is present in the IR spectra of all the forms studied (Figure S4a). This band is absent in the spectrum of 1,1'-ferrocenediyl-bis(H-phosphinic acid). Thus, coordinative bonds (P)O-Mn are still preserved in the dehydrated forms of complex 2. Further evidence of this is provided by comparison of Raman spectra of the acid Fc(PHOOH)2 and crystals 2 and 2' (Figure S3). The spectra of the latter two species in low-frequency region, where vibrations of the coordinative bonds are expected to contribute essentially, practically coincide with each other and differ essentially from the spectrum of the noncoordinated acid.

elements.content: The original structure of 2 can be restored by exposition of coordination polymer 2′ to water. When 2′ was treated with H2O vapor, the powder X-ray diffraction pattern expectedly changed back to that of the as-synthesized compound 2 (). The same is clearly seen in the IR spectrum of the resolvated sample, which practically coincides with the spectrum of the freshly synthesized 2 (Figure S4b). All of these results confirm reversible water-induced phase transformation in the supramolecular network of 2.
elements.clean_text: The original structure of 2 can be restored by exposition of coordination polymer 2' to water. When 2' was treated with H2O vapor, the powder X-ray diffraction pattern expectedly changed back to that of the as-synthesized compound 2 (). The same is clearly seen in the IR spectrum of the resolvated sample, which practically coincides with the spectrum of the freshly synthesized 2 (Figure S4b). All of these results confirm reversible water-induced phase transformation in the supramolecular network of 2.

elements.content:
The porosity of the compound after dehydration was investigated by nitrogen physisorption at 77 K, and it was shown that the compound 2′ is not accessible for nitrogen molecules.

In contrast, the compound adsorbs water vapor at 298 K. Starting from low pressure, a slowly growing uptake can be observed up to p/p 0 0.8, followed by a steep rise in the adsorbed amount at relative pressures above 0.8 (). Such a profile of adsorption isotherm can be explained by the flexible behavior of the network during water sorption. The Type II adsorption isotherm transforms to Type I, which indicates the structural rearrangement of the MOF at “gate opening” pressure. The uptake in saturation corresponds well to the four H2O molecules per formula unit and 17% weight loss observed from TG curve. Thus, the activated compound is able to adsorb water selectively over other solvents. The desorption branch of the isotherm does not fit the adsorption branch, forming a broad hysteresis, which is also characteristic for “gate-pressure” MOFs. Obviously, the incorporated water molecules cannot be easily desorbed even at low relative pressure. To desorb water molecules, heating is needed in addition to evacuation. Moreover, one should note that the desorption process of 2 significantly differs from that observed in other flexible porous coordination polymers containing both coordinated and crystal lattice water molecules. Many of them start to lose lattice water already at ambient conditions, the others exhibit step-like water desorption curves, while 2 is extremely stable at room temperature and loses all four water molecules in one step upon heating.
elements.clean_text:
Physisorption Studies

The porosity of the compound after dehydration was investigated by nitrogen physisorption at 77 K, and it was shown that the compound 2' is not accessible for nitrogen molecules.

In contrast, the compound adsorbs water vapor at 298 K. Starting from low pressure, a slowly growing uptake can be observed up to p/p 0 0.8, followed by a steep rise in the adsorbed amount at relative pressures above 0.8 (). Such a profile of adsorption isotherm can be explained by the flexible behavior of the network during water sorption. The Type II adsorption isotherm transforms to Type I, which indicates the structural rearrangement of the MOF at "gate opening" pressure. The uptake in saturation corresponds well to the four H2O molecules per formula unit and 17% weight loss observed from TG curve. Thus, the activated compound is able to adsorb water selectively over other solvents. The desorption branch of the isotherm does not fit the adsorption branch, forming a broad hysteresis, which is also characteristic for "gate-pressure" MOFs. Obviously, the incorporated water molecules cannot be easily desorbed even at low relative pressure. To desorb water molecules, heating is needed in addition to evacuation. Moreover, one should note that the desorption process of 2 significantly differs from that observed in other flexible porous coordination polymers containing both coordinated and crystal lattice water molecules. Many of them start to lose lattice water already at ambient conditions, the others exhibit step-like water desorption curves, while 2 is extremely stable at room temperature and loses all four water molecules in one step upon heating.

elements.content: Adsorption (closed symbols) and desorption (open symbols) isotherms of H2O vapor (298 K) (black circles - cycle 1, and red squares - cycle 2), and MeOH (298 K) (blue triangles) for 2′.
elements.clean_text: 4  Adsorption (closed symbols) and desorption (open symbols) isotherms of H2O vapor (298 K) (black circles - cycle 1, and red squares - cycle 2), and MeOH (298 K) (blue triangles) for 2'.

elements.content: The water adsorption/water removal process is completely reversible and can be repeated. In the second water vapor adsorption cycle, after sample evacuation at 150 °C overnight, the amount of water adsorbed and the shape of adsorption isotherm remain the same ().
elements.clean_text: The water adsorption/water removal process is completely reversible and can be repeated. In the second water vapor adsorption cycle, after sample evacuation at 150 °C overnight, the amount of water adsorbed and the shape of adsorption isotherm remain the same ().

elements.content: Interestingly, the dehydrated form 2′ is not accessible for plenty of other solvents such as methanol, ethanol, N,N-dimethylformamide, tetrahydrofuran, and acetone. After treatment of the compound 2′ with selected solvents, no changes in the XRD patterns were observed. The lack of uptake of the solvents mentioned was also confirmed by the adsorption experiments from the gas phase (MeOH was used as a representative solvent). The sorption study at 298 K shows that there is no uptake of methanol up to high relative pressures ().
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the dehydrated form 2' is not accessible for plenty of other solvents such as methanol, ethanol, N,N-dimethylformamide, tetrahydrofuran, and acetone. After treatment of the compound 2' with selected solvents, no changes in the XRD patterns were observed. The lack of uptake of the solvents mentioned was also confirmed by the adsorption experiments from the gas phase (MeOH was used as a representative solvent). The sorption study at 298 K shows that there is no uptake of methanol up to high relative pressures ().

elements.content: Although coordination polymers based on phosphorus acids are widespread just several examples of PCP based on phosphinic acids are known in the literature. Midollini et al. showed that copper­(II) diphosphinate coordination polymers based on P,P′-diphenylmethylenediphosphinic or P,P′-diphenyl-p-xylenediphosphinic undergo water-induced structural transformations. Moreover, some carboxylate-phosphinates also demonstrated the water-depending structural transformations. We suppose that formation of multiple hydrogen bonds between water molecules and phosphinate groups together with flexibility of the phosphinic moiety contribute to the easy structural transformations of phosphinates-based MOFs. The ferrocene linker provides the formation of the 2D network. Though some examples of the ferrocene based carboxylate or sulfonate coordination polymers are known, the MOFs are rarely reported, and those exhibiting reversible dynamic behavior upon adsorption/desorption as well as showing selective gas or vapor adsorption are not known yet.
elements.clean_text: Although coordination polymers based on phosphorus acids are widespread just several examples of PCP based on phosphinic acids are known in the literature. Midollini et al. showed that copper(II) diphosphinate coordination polymers based on P,P'-diphenylmethylenediphosphinic or P,P'-diphenyl-p-xylenediphosphinic undergo water-induced structural transformations. Moreover, some carboxylate-phosphinates also demonstrated the water-depending structural transformations. We suppose that formation of multiple hydrogen bonds between water molecules and phosphinate groups together with flexibility of the phosphinic moiety contribute to the easy structural transformations of phosphinates-based MOFs. The ferrocene linker provides the formation of the 2D network. Though some examples of the ferrocene based carboxylate or sulfonate coordination polymers are known, the MOFs are rarely reported, and those exhibiting reversible dynamic behavior upon adsorption/desorption as well as showing selective gas or vapor adsorption are not known yet.

elements.content: Measurements of the static magnetization (M) were performed in the temperature range 1.8–300 K in magnetic fields up to 7 T. Temperature dependence of the static magnetic susceptibility χ­(T) = M(T)/H (where H is the applied magnetic field) and of the inverse susceptibility χ–1(T) for 2 and 2′ are presented in , panels a and b, respectively. The experimentally obtained dependences can be well fitted with a Curie–Weiss law χ = C/(T + θ) + χ0. Here C is a Curie constant, θ is a Curie–Weiss temperature, and χ0 is a temperature independent (predominantly diamagnetic) contribution to the magnetic susceptibility. The fitting curves are shown by black solid lines in a,b. This analysis yields the Curie constants of 4.9 and 4.6 emu/mol, which correspond to the effective magnetic moment μeff of 6.3 μB and 6.1 μB, for 2 and 2′, respectively (μB is the Bohr magneton). Knowing the g-factor of 2.02 obtained from the electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements (see Figure S5) and using the relation μeff = g[S(S+1)]1/2 μB, we can estimate the effective spin value S eff ≈ 2.65 and 2.56 per formula unit for 2 and 2′, respectively. Considering the quantum nature of the spin, the obtained values have to be rounded to the nearest half-integer or integer number. In both cases we obtain the spin value S = 5/2, as expected for the Mn2+ ion (3d5) in the high-spin state. For an accurate quantification of the magnetic moment we have measured the field dependence of the magnetization M(H) at a low temperature (see below). The values of the Curie–Weiss temperature θ obtained from the χ­(T) dependence are positive and very similar for both compounds being on the order of 6–7 K (4–5 cm–1). They indicate the antiferromagnetic coupling between Mn spins with a similar strength of a few cm–1 in both cases. Interestingly, the χ­(T) dependence of 2 tends to saturation below 3 K (a, inset), while in the case of 2′ (b, inset) no saturation is observed.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties of 2 and 2' 

Measurements of the static magnetization (M) were performed in the temperature range 1.8-300 K in magnetic fields up to 7 T. Temperature dependence of the static magnetic susceptibility χ(T) = M(T)/H (where H is the applied magnetic field) and of the inverse susceptibility χ-1(T) for 2 and 2' are presented in , panels a and b, respectively. The experimentally obtained dependences can be well fitted with a Curie-Weiss law χ = C/(T + θ) + χ0. Here C is a Curie constant, θ is a Curie-Weiss temperature, and χ0 is a temperature independent (predominantly diamagnetic) contribution to the magnetic susceptibility. The fitting curves are shown by black solid lines in a,b. This analysis yields the Curie constants of 4.9 and 4.6 emu/mol, which correspond to the effective magnetic moment μeff of 6.3 μB and 6.1 μB, for 2 and 2', respectively (μB is the Bohr magneton). Knowing the g-factor of 2.02 obtained from the electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements (see Figure S5) and using the relation μeff = g[S(S+1)]1/2 μB, we can estimate the effective spin value S eff ~ 2.65 and 2.56 per formula unit for 2 and 2', respectively. Considering the quantum nature of the spin, the obtained values have to be rounded to the nearest half-integer or integer number. In both cases we obtain the spin value S = 5/2, as expected for the Mn2+ ion (3d5) in the high-spin state. For an accurate quantification of the magnetic moment we have measured the field dependence of the magnetization M(H) at a low temperature (see below). The values of the Curie-Weiss temperature θ obtained from the χ(T) dependence are positive and very similar for both compounds being on the order of 6-7 K (4-5 cm-1). They indicate the antiferromagnetic coupling between Mn spins with a similar strength of a few cm-1 in both cases. Interestingly, the χ(T) dependence of 2 tends to saturation below 3 K (a, inset), while in the case of 2' (b, inset) no saturation is observed.

elements.content: Temperature dependences of the static magnetic susceptibility χ­(T) = M(T)/H and of the inverse susceptibility χ–1(T) for 2 (a) and 2′ (b) measured in an external magnetic field of 1 T. The insets show the χ­(T) data in the low temperature range. Black solid lines represent the result of the fitting to the Curie–Weiss law.
elements.clean_text: 5  Temperature dependences of the static magnetic susceptibility χ(T) = M(T)/H and of the inverse susceptibility χ-1(T) for 2 (a) and 2' (b) measured in an external magnetic field of 1 T. The insets show the χ(T) data in the low temperature range. Black solid lines represent the result of the fitting to the Curie-Weiss law.

elements.content: Indeed, the distinct magnetic behavior at low temperatures is corroborated by measurements of the magnetic field dependence of the static magnetization M(H) of 2 and 2′ at T = 1.8 K (). In both cases the measured M(H) curves substantially deviate from a dependence of noninteracting Mn ions which is represented in by a Brillouin function with S = 5/2 (dashed line). Compared to this, the magnetization of 2 shows a much weaker dependence at small fields, and then it increases more steeply above a field of ∼2 T and reaches the saturation value M sat = 5.08 μB in a field of 7 T. The obtained saturation moment nicely agrees with the value expected for Mn ions in the high spin state M sat = gSμ B = 5.05 μB with the ESR g-factor of 2.02 and the spin quantum number S = 5/2. An inflection point in the M(H) curve of 2 occurring at ∼2 T indicates a spin-flip transition which is expected to occur in a low-dimensional spin network when the magnetic Zeeman energy overcomes the antiferromagnetic coupling energy of the interacting spins. The M(H) curve of 2′ does not exhibit this feature. The magnetization increases almost linearly up to a field of ∼3 T. At stronger field the M(H) dependence shows a saturation tendency to the same value M sat = 5.05 μB, though the full saturation is not yet reached at the highest field of the measurement. Such a distinct magnetic behavior appears as a noticeable feature of the investigated compounds.
elements.clean_text: Indeed, the distinct magnetic behavior at low temperatures is corroborated by measurements of the magnetic field dependence of the static magnetization M(H) of 2 and 2' at T = 1.8 K (). In both cases the measured M(H) curves substantially deviate from a dependence of noninteracting Mn ions which is represented in  by a Brillouin function with S = 5/2 (dashed line). Compared to this, the magnetization of 2 shows a much weaker dependence at small fields, and then it increases more steeply above a field of ~2 T and reaches the saturation value M sat = 5.08 μB in a field of 7 T. The obtained saturation moment nicely agrees with the value expected for Mn ions in the high spin state M sat = gSμ B = 5.05 μB with the ESR g-factor of 2.02 and the spin quantum number S = 5/2. An inflection point in the M(H) curve of 2 occurring at ~2 T indicates a spin-flip transition which is expected to occur in a low-dimensional spin network when the magnetic Zeeman energy overcomes the antiferromagnetic coupling energy of the interacting spins. The M(H) curve of 2' does not exhibit this feature. The magnetization increases almost linearly up to a field of ~3 T. At stronger field the M(H) dependence shows a saturation tendency to the same value M sat = 5.05 μB, though the full saturation is not yet reached at the highest field of the measurement. Such a distinct magnetic behavior appears as a noticeable feature of the investigated compounds.

elements.content: Magnetic field dependence of the static magnetization M(T) of 2 and 2′. The green dashed line represents the Brillouin function for spin S = 5/2 and g-factor 2.02.
elements.clean_text: 6  Magnetic field dependence of the static magnetization M(T) of 2 and 2'. The green dashed line represents the Brillouin function for spin S = 5/2 and g-factor 2.02.

elements.content: Metal–organic framework [Mn­(H2O)2­(Fc­(PHOO)2·2H2O] n based on the ferrocene ligand containing bisphosphinate groups is the first example of a flexible MOF of the third generation based on ferrocene. The compound is capable of reversible crystal structure transformation and can switch between two different stable forms: hydrated Mn­(H2O)2­(Fc­(PHOO)2)­·2H2O and dehydrated Mn­(Fc­(PHOO)2). The stability of the hydrated sample is provided by multiple hydrogen bond interactions with participation of phosphinate groups and lattice and coordinated water molecules. If all water molecules leave the framework, the 2D coordination network is preserved, as is evident from IR spectroscopy, but the long-range order is lost according to powder X-ray diffraction data. This transformation is reversible, and the dehydrated compound can adsorb H2O molecules selectively over other possible adsorptives such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, and tetrahydrofuran at 298 K, making it an excellent material for drying purposes and for water/alcohol separations.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Metal-organic framework [Mn(H2O)2(Fc(PHOO)2⋅2H2O] n  based on the ferrocene ligand containing bisphosphinate groups is the first example of a flexible MOF of the third generation based on ferrocene. The compound is capable of reversible crystal structure transformation and can switch between two different stable forms: hydrated Mn(H2O)2(Fc(PHOO)2)⋅2H2O and dehydrated Mn(Fc(PHOO)2). The stability of the hydrated sample is provided by multiple hydrogen bond interactions with participation of phosphinate groups and lattice and coordinated water molecules. If all water molecules leave the framework, the 2D coordination network is preserved, as is evident from IR spectroscopy, but the long-range order is lost according to powder X-ray diffraction data. This transformation is reversible, and the dehydrated compound can adsorb H2O molecules selectively over other possible adsorptives such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, and tetrahydrofuran at 298 K, making it an excellent material for drying purposes and for water/alcohol separations.

elements.content: Thus, the system exhibits a rare combination of properties: flexibility accompanied by high hydrolytic stability and the ability to selectively adsorb water. The structural transformations are also reflected in a change of magnetic properties of the MOF, making it an interesting candidate for sensing applications.
elements.clean_text: Thus, the system exhibits a rare combination of properties: flexibility accompanied by high hydrolytic stability and the ability to selectively adsorb water. The structural transformations are also reflected in a change of magnetic properties of the MOF, making it an interesting candidate for sensing applications.

cln_elements.content:
All chemicals were used as purchased without further purification. The 1,1′-ferrocenediyl-bis­(H-phosphinic acid) (1) was prepared as previously described.

Synthesis of [Mn­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>­(Fc­(PHOO)<sub>2</sub>)­·2H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

MnCl2·4H2O (31.7 mg; 0.16 mmol) and Fc­(P­(O)­(H)­OH)2 (50.2 mg; 0.16 mmol) were dissolved in 4 mL of a water/acetone mixture (1:3). After several hours at room temperature, orange crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 67.3 mg (96%) based on 1,1′-ferrocenediyl-bis­(H-phosphinic acid).

Anal. Calcd for 2 C10H18FeMnO8P2 (438.98 g/mol): C: 27.40; H: 4.10%. Found: C: 27.49; H: 4.31%. IR (nujol, cm–1): 3380 s, 3130 w, 3112 w, 2443 m, 1637 s, 1563 m, 1425 m, 1325 m, 1193 s, 1185 s, 1140 vs, 1063 sh, 1047 vs, 1037 s, 1028 s, 992 s, 925 w, 909 m, 879 m, 838 s, 649 s, 529 s, 492 s, 475 s, 457 s.

Synthesis of [Mn­(FcPHOO<sub>2</sub>)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2′</bold>)

The compound 2′ was obtained by drying 2 under vacuum for 24 h at 150 °C. Removal of all solvent molecules was proved by thermogravimetric analysis. Anal. Calcd for 2′ C10H10FeMnO4P2 (366.91 g/mol): C: 32.70; H: 2.72%. Found: C: 32.53; H: 3.01%. IR (nujol, cm–1): 3386 w, 3097 w, 2340 m, 1574 w, 1425 m, 1313 w, 1189 vs, 1180 vs, 1163 vs, 1070 s, 1051 s, 1016 s, 986 s, 897 m, 837 m, 642 s, 472 s.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Syntheses

All chemicals were used as purchased without further purification. The 1,1'-ferrocenediyl-bis(H-phosphinic acid) (1) was prepared as previously described. 

Synthesis of [Mn(H2O)2(Fc(PHOO)2)⋅2H2O] n  (2)

MnCl2⋅4H2O (31.7 mg; 0.16 mmol) and Fc(P(O)(H)OH)2 (50.2 mg; 0.16 mmol) were dissolved in 4 mL of a water/acetone mixture (1:3). After several hours at room temperature, orange crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 67.3 mg (96%) based on 1,1'-ferrocenediyl-bis(H-phosphinic acid).

Anal. Calcd for 2 C10H18FeMnO8P2 (438.98 g/mol): C: 27.40; H: 4.10%. Found: C: 27.49; H: 4.31%. IR (nujol, cm-1): 3380 s, 3130 w, 3112 w, 2443 m, 1637 s, 1563 m, 1425 m, 1325 m, 1193 s, 1185 s, 1140 vs, 1063 sh, 1047 vs, 1037 s, 1028 s, 992 s, 925 w, 909 m, 879 m, 838 s, 649 s, 529 s, 492 s, 475 s, 457 s.

Synthesis of [Mn(FcPHOO2)] n  (2')

The compound 2' was obtained by drying 2 under vacuum for 24 h at 150 °C. Removal of all solvent molecules was proved by thermogravimetric analysis. Anal. Calcd for 2' C10H10FeMnO4P2 (366.91 g/mol): C: 32.70; H: 2.72%. Found: C: 32.53; H: 3.01%. IR (nujol, cm-1): 3386 w, 3097 w, 2340 m, 1574 w, 1425 m, 1313 w, 1189 vs, 1180 vs, 1163 vs, 1070 s, 1051 s, 1016 s, 986 s, 897 m, 837 m, 642 s, 472 s.

cln_elements.content:
Formula C10H18FeMnO8P2, M = 438.97, a = 10.199(2), b = 5.5056(13), c = 13.333(3) Å, β = 99.605(2)°, V = 738.1(3) Å3, ρcalc = 1.975 g cm–3, μ = 2.091 mm–1, semiempirical absorption correction, Z = 2 (molecule in a special position), monoclinic, space group P21 /c (No. 14), ω scans, 5288 reflections collected (±h, ± k, ± l), [(sin θ)/λ] = 0.62 Å–1, 1449 independent (R int = 0.030) and 1156 observed reflections [I ≥ 2σ­(I)], 139 refined parameters, R = 0.028, wR 2 = 0.069, max. residual electron density 0.323 (−0.366) e·Å–3, hydrogen atoms were localized in the difference Fourier map and refined isotropically.

Crystal Structure Transformations during Water Removal

The water molecules can be removed from the structure by heating (Figure S6). Compound 2 loses all four H2O molecules (coordinated and lattice water; 17 wt %) in the temperature range of 65–155 °C transforming into the dehydrated form Mn­(Fc­(PHOO)2) (2′) which is stable up to 260 °C.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Crystal Data for 2 

Formula C10H18FeMnO8P2, M = 438.97, a = 10.199(2), b = 5.5056(13), c = 13.333(3) Å, β = 99.605(2)°, V = 738.1(3) Å3, ρcalc = 1.975 g cm-3, μ = 2.091 mm-1, semiempirical absorption correction, Z = 2 (molecule in a special position), monoclinic, space group P21 /c (No. 14), ω scans, 5288 reflections collected (±h, ± k, ± l), [(sin θ)/λ] = 0.62 Å-1, 1449 independent (R int = 0.030) and 1156 observed reflections [I ≥ 2σ(I)], 139 refined parameters, R = 0.028, wR 2 = 0.069, max. residual electron density 0.323 (-0.366) e⋅Å-3, hydrogen atoms were localized in the difference Fourier map and refined isotropically.

Crystal Structure Transformations during Water Removal

The water molecules can be removed from the structure by heating (Figure S6). Compound 2 loses all four H2O molecules (coordinated and lattice water; 17 wt %) in the temperature range of 65-155 °C transforming into the dehydrated form Mn(Fc(PHOO)2) (2') which is stable up to 260 °C.

metadata.title:
Reversible Water-Induced Structural and Magnetic Transformations
and Selective Water Adsorption Properties of Poly(manganese 1,1′-ferrocenediyl-bis(H-phosphinate))
